While raiding Berk's Squab Farm, Mr. Fox and his wife Felicity trigger a fox trap and become caged. Felicity reveals to Fox that she is pregnant and pleads with him to find a safer job when they escape.

Two years later (twelve in Fox Years), the Foxes and their sullen son Ash are living in a hole. Fox, now a newspaper columnist, moves the family into a better home in the base of a tree, ignoring the warnings of his lawyer Badger about how dangerous the area is for foxes. The tree is located very close to facilities run by three mean farmers consisting of Walter Boggis, Nathaniel Bunce, and Franklin Bean. Soon after the Foxes move in, Felicity's nephew Kristofferson Silverfox comes to live with them as his father has become very ill with double pneumonia. Ash finds this situation intolerable; his soft-spoken cousin is apparently superior to him at almost everything, and everyone, including his father, Mr. Fox, is charmed by Kristofferson at Ash's expense.

Fox and Kylie Opossum steal produce and poultry from the three farms. The farmers decide to kill Fox and camp out near the family's tree. When Fox emerges, the farmers open fire, but manage only to shoot off his tail. They then attempt to dig Fox out. After demolishing the site of the tree, the farmers discover the Foxes have dug an escape tunnel.

Reasoning that the Foxes will have to surface for food and water, the farmers lie in wait at the tunnel mouth. Underground, Fox encounters Badger and many other local animal residents whose homes have also been destroyed. As the animals begin fearing starvation, Fox leads Clive Badger, Mole, Beaver, and Weasel in a digging expedition to tunnel to the three farms, robbing them clean. While the other animals feast, Ash and Kristofferson, beginning to reconcile after Kristofferson defended Ash from Mr. Beaver's son, return to Bean's farm, intending to reclaim Mr. Fox's tail. When they are interrupted by the arrival of Bean's wife, Ash escapes but Kristofferson is captured.

Discovering that Fox has stolen their produce, the farmers flood the animals' tunnel network with cider. The animals are forced into the sewers and Fox learns that the farmers plan to use Kristofferson to lure him into an ambush. The animals are confronted by Rat, Bean's security guard. Fox and Rat fight in an electrical room until Fox pushes him into an electric generator, severely electrocuting him. Rat confesses Kristofferson's location before his death.

Fox asks the farmers for a meeting in town near the sewer hub where he would surrender in exchange for Kristofferson's freedom. The farmers set up an ambush, but Fox and the others anticipate it and launch a counterattack. Fox, Ash and Kylie slip into Bean's farm. A much-matured Ash frees Kristofferson and braves enemy fire to release a rabid beagle named Spitz to keep the farmers at bay.

The animals become accustomed to living in the sewers with others considering moving in. Ash and Kristofferson settle their differences and become good friends. Fox leads his family to a drain opening built into the floor of a supermarket owned by the three farmers. Celebrating their new food source and the news that Felicity is pregnant again, the animals dance in their aisles.

One of the best animated films ever! Wes Anderson's style of filming makes this an even more enjoyable film with all the actors and actresses voicing the characters. Well done Wes! Well done George! 93/100
Think about taking pictures over and over. It would've takin so long to finish the movie! This movie is just amazing.
Great Animated movie. There wasn't much problems at all either! I was enjoyed all the way through. This movie should be a funny live action ride for you! Overall grade: A-
Nobody does this better!

There are those who don't like this film, who critise it for not being what Dahl would of wanted. These are the cynics who are completely oblivious to its sheer genius. This film is everything a Dahl film should be. Its deliriously funny, completely incomprehensible and astoundingly crafted. Wes Anderson, I say this to you now, this is not only an achievement in stop motion but an animated masterpiece. And who the hell on God's green earth cant love the fabulous voices of George Clooney and Meryl Streep? The screenplay is tender, charming, witty and first and foremost enjoyably sensational. Not since The Nightmare Before Christmas (excluding claymation) has stop motion been so splendid. It seems, like James and the Giant Peach, Dahl's books are best for stop motion. This is competing against Up for best animated picture at the oscars and I know I gave it the same rating, but this is simply that little bit better and more nuanced. Anyone who says that animation cant live up to the standards of live-action is bloody kidding themselves. And this film prooves that in spades
this is how animation is done.
A slick and nostalgic animation with charismatic characters and funny as hell dialogue. I've smiled through every frame of this somewhat eccentric movie and I believe everyone should watch it.
Really smart, really funny, really different. One of the great jewels of Anderson's genius.
Brilliantly animated and the voice cast is perfect. Lots of fun.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a charming story adapted to the screen and directed by Wes Anderson. The animation is gorgeous in this finely crafted film, and George Clooney adds some wit to the character of Mr. Fox. The film is great family fare, very funny and mature.

The contrast between the utter beauty of the beggining and the bleak enviroments of the second half is notable, but the movie still manages to tell a pretty funny and adventurous tale that isnt anything terribly original when the audience takes into account all the other animated films out there, but the movie still has plenty of impressive and fun moments that combined with the great cast and awesome characters make up one of the most *fantastic* animated feauture films out there.
Wes Anderson exhibits complete control over his animated characters and delivers a film full of heart and wit and inventive filmmaking. Full review later.
I really did like this movie and thought it does great justice to Rohald Dahl's great book but I found it to be a bit on the short side and some of the characters to be a bit gimmicky.
I am sucker for Wes Anderson flicks. It was a great homage to one of my most favorite books to read.
The not-so-Fantastic Mr Fox pointlessly embellishes an already brilliant book and turns it into a creepy, witless and overwrought piece of cinematic claptrap.
Finally watched this and loved it. Clever and uplifting.
This is one of my favorites now! Stop animation live on.
As charming and original as any Wes Anderson Film. But feels a bit to long for me
My full opinion: The plot is fun, the soundtrack is good, and the animation looks great. Almost look a lot like Aardman Animation films, but all done by style, and big humor by Wes Anderson. 8.3/10
Wes does it again, I love all his movies,
A delightful beautifully animated comedy for the whole family to enjoy
I believe the pairing of Wes Anderson and Roald Dahl was quite a success, even with the many liberties taken.
The style is a tad distracting; even for me; but The Fantastic Mr. Fox is still filled with Anderson's typical whimsy and clever humor.
Human nature and animal instinct join together side by side to highlight how fantastic being different from the pack can be.

A delightful and charming stop motion film about a struggling fox. The quirky and detailed writing makes insures the Wes Anderson staple of filmmaking. It is also beautifully animated and features top-notch voice acting.
very clever, very fun to watch
I know of no other animated movie quite like it--it's funny, dark at times, and consistently inventive.

Inspiring steady charm, beautifully creative animation, and top-notch voice acting help Anderson prove that even the king of adult quirk and irony can market multi-layered intelligent feel goods to audiences of all ages.
Boasting beautiful and unique animation, a witty screenplay and great characters, 'Fantastic Mr. Fox' finds Wes Anderson at his finest.

If you haven't watch this then you are a fool.
@kenrick
Charming, fast paced, well written, and beautifully directed by Wes Anderson. This is definitely one of my favorite animated films of all time and one of Wes Anderson's best films in my opinion.
Most outstanding visualization and voice overs

Review In A Nutshell:

Animation has been, in recent years, a bit predictable and safe. Disney films, with only some as an exception, have taken familiar a formula to drive almost all of their films with only a minor set of tweaks, hoping it would be enough to create a sense of originality. In the hand-drawn animation department, Studio Ghibli is winning the battle with their bold and graceful artistic choices, fuelled by a sense of imagination and hidden symbolism. Pixar has established themselves as the leaders of three-dimensional computer graphic animations to create wonderful stories that deliver multi-generational accessibility and richly appealing characters and worlds. Fantastic Mr. Fox belongs in the underrated category of stop-animation films, which is an area of animated filmmaking that rarely gains a large audience, as some feel it lacks the realism and wonder that other modes of animation could deliver, and the difficult process of creating such a feature does not entirely justify the benefits of the finished product.

I believe that animation should not be limited by its two popular options. There are gems found in a stop-motion animated film that easily becomes lost when told in another medium. If Fantastic Mr. Fox was told through hand-drawn animation then all of its three-dimensional charm is lost, creating flat characters and a world lacking in complexity. Using three-dimensional computer graphics could achieve that extra dimensions that the hand-drawn animations lack, but they tend to give that smooth texture that keeps the film from seeming life-like, also the comedic aspect of the film wouldn't have been achieved as effectively if told in this way. Stop-motion animation may not be the most deliver the smoothest of movement from its characters, but it doesn't have to because what we are seeing are actual living objects that are interacting with one another, which is hard to convey with the other two options.

The film was under the direction of visual director, Wes Anderson, and what he brings to this is a sense of style that is certainly familiar to the fans that have been long following his work, but it also brings something entirely different and unique to the realm of stop-motion animation; the film is leaps and bounds beyond Chicken Little and the Wallace and Gromit films. Anderson's visual and artistic trademarks are here and they are on full display, giving the characters and their world a sense of strangeness and eccentricity, gaining a sense of escape during the experience; but since Anderson is handling fictional characters rather than human projections, their personalities do not seem as odd or intense as his previous films. It actually allows it to become easier for a person, who is unfamiliar with the director, to come into this and still feel like they just experienced another run-of-the-mill animated film; and Anderson knew his target audience and what their expectations were. If he decided to crank up his usual style to maximum, just so the film would really stand out from its peers, then itâ??s going to have people turn their heads and probably lose the natural charm that made the film so appealing.

I cannot note in this review whether the film remained true to Roald Dahl's novel, as I have yet to read it; therefore do not expect any comparisons here, and everything I would state or judge on the film's story would be purely based on the film itself. Wes Anderson returns as the film's screenwriter, collaborating once again with his friend Noah Baumbach to create Fantastic Mr. Fox. I was a little sceptical on whether or not I would find myself pleased with the film, as when they both worked together previously on The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou, I was left disappointed and so far I have regarded it as Anderson's weakest film. After watching this, I was a little stunned on how much I actually enjoyed it. It provided a simple and accessible story, but made it feel mature and complex in its core relationships. They treat the film's characters with effort and respect, demonstrating layers that shape their outer personality and acts as drives to the logic of their decision-making. Dialogue is another thing that the film does wonderfully well, with characters seemingly distinctive and back and forth chatter that is not only hilarious but also thoughtful; it coveys its themes through the intentions and values of its characters, ensuring that the film is about them and not something much larger, like what was done in The Darjeeling Limited. The film also manages to be risky in its choice of words, bringing up themes that seem inappropriate for a young person to hear but hidden cleverly enough behind their hilarious remarks and witty substitution of particular words. They achieve all of this while also providing, assumingly, a faithful interpretation from the source material. Anderson and Baumbach have delivered a screenplay that is both superficially entertaining and emotionally insightful.

The film starts off as a fox couple who live their lives as bandits, benefiting from the riches of their loot, then suddenly Mrs. Fox announces her pregnancy which forces both of them to turn their life around and become a settled and honest family. From there, years later Mr. Fox decides to get back in the game and do one more grand scheme, but then things get out of hand and their entire community becomes affected by his actions. His journey was fun, wild, and tense; there were sequences in here that I would probably never forget, but the film is not really about the spectacle, it's about the relationships and drives of its characters. Mr. Fox is an individual who is driven by his ego, who basks in the glow of success. His sudden change to a "normal" life was manageable at first, but as time went by, it becomes much more difficult to live such a mundane and tedious life where no one even appreciates the writing contributions he brings to the local newspaper. His personality and high expectations also contributes to the dysfunction between him and his son, which is something Anderson treads on frequently with his films. He expects his son to be naturally talented, similar to himself, and passively shows disappointment when he isn't able to fulfil his expectations. It is relationships like these in the film, that makes these characters feel real and complex, rather than empty vessels who's aim is to push the plot forward; it also gives the film naturally earned emotions that aid in the growth of its characters.

Along with its themes of ego and family dysfunction, the film also touches on the idea of adaptation. The film shows us by the end of the film, the determination of these characters to survive in such a difficult and selfish world. In whatever habitat that these animals are put in, they are able to make the best of it, and slowly in their own way fighting and taking back from humans what is rightfully theirs.

Robert Yeoman sadly does not come back here for Fantastic Mr. Fox, and that is understandable as it would take a person who has deep experience of stop-motion animation, and who better than Tristan Oliver, who has previously worked on films including Chicken Run and Wallace and Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit. He is able to do this while still staying close to the vision of the director, emphasising the centred shots and the sudden push-ins and pull-outs. I also cherished the film's orange-brown warm glow to its image, giving it that earth-like feel to it. It was also disappointing to find that Mark Mothersbaugh did not come back to compose the score for Fantastic Mr. Fox, and instead done so by Alexandre Desplat. Desplat is an amazing composer, and his so-far three films with Anderson have been fantastic but there is just something about a long-time collaboration that makes it seem more connected and fantastic. Mothersbaugh brought a lot of charm to Anderson's films, and because of him a lot of his early films sound and feel beautiful. Desplat has a different approach, it has this magical, larger than life quality to his scores, and Fantastic Mr. Fox is one of his more grounded and child-like works, which suited to the film's story and characters. I don't know why I even decided to make a comparison if Desplat did an equally strong enough job in this film. I think I just cannot help but wonder on what the film would have sounded like if it Mothersbaugh was under the role instead.

The film's cast was fantastic, as expected, with new members joining Anderson's troupe; George Clooney and Meryl Streep. Both were perfect choices of casting, demonstrating effective and heavy chemistry between the two, allowing the emotional scenes of the film feel natural. The rest of the cast are familiar members of Anderson's filmography; Bill Murray, Owen Wilson, Jason Schwartzman, Willem Dafoe, Michael Gambon, Adrien Brody and Brian Cox. All of them do a wonderful job with their characters, especially Jason Schwartzman.

Fantastic Mr. Fox feels like a refinement of Steve Zissou, executing character-driven stories with large and ambitious action sequences; laying the groundwork for his audience of the direction of his future as a filmmaker.

I have actually never watched this whole film, and the only reason I've seen parts of it is because I live with someone who watches it every time it comes on TV.  Wes Anderson can be twee even at the best of times, but this film definitely crosses a line with me where folksy dialogue and mannered quirks aren't even cute when manifested by woodland creatures.  I remember really enjoying this book as a kid, and I can't understand why he had to force it into his own same old tired format.

One of the most entertaining, funny, clever and wonderfully voiced animated film I've ever seen.  Wes Anderson's screen adaptation is brilliantly cast, uniquely animated as clever as the cast who voice the main characters.

One of my favorite stop motion films. Yet when I first saw this film, I had no clue who the heck was Wes Anderson is. I didn't even see his movies. But as his first film I've seen from him & being his first animated, family film, it really pays off.
Story: 8/10

Characters: 8/10
Total: 8/10

There's a lot to be said about a Wes Anderson film; the composition is nearly, always perfect, the characters written are admirably, adorably quirky. The cast is unusually well balanced and the story always goes in a direction you never expect it to go. The same can be said about the absolutely brilliant and wonderful Fantastic Mr. Fox, which douses the viewer in autumn hues and takes them on an inspiring journey of imaginative visuals and story telling, teaching the importance of family and friends nd their commitment of what another (as well as reaching out to the wild animal inside each and every one of us). Based on the story by Roald Dahl, this film is just as entertaining for children as it is for adults and the animation is a wonder to watch. Everyone should take time out of their busy schedule at some point to sit down and watch this film with friend, family, someone you hold dear in your heart. You won't be disappointed!

Mr. Fox was the most successful chicken thief ever. After a close brush with death alongside his wife, he vowed to never put himself or his family in danger again by refraining from stealing anymore chickens. 12 fox years later, with a child in school and his somewhat successful column in the daily newspaper, Mr. Fox feels unsatisfied with his state of life. He decides to go back on his vow to his wife by performing three last chicken heists against the most dangerous chicken farmers in the land. The jobs, though successful, cause the farmers to be vindictive and attempt to destroy everything Mr. Fox loves. Now with his dishonesty in the open, he not only finds himself and his family endangered but the entire animal community as well unless he can change who he is and use his cunning wit in defense of others instead of his own personal gain.
Clever, witty, and pretty humorous. Though the animation and comedy may not appeal to some, the messages that I thought were present should ring a bell with many families. Responsibility and family over personal desires, accepting yourself if you're in the shadow of someone "greater", treating family with love and respect, revenge being more hurtful than good, etc etc. George Clooney was fantastic (pun) in this role. Character traits are well developed and the script was really well written. The humor was frequent, but not over bearing. The best part was seeing how Mr. Fox can change without giving up his traits that truly makes him "fantastic". Awesome movie. I would watch it again multiple times.
Though odd at times,Fantastic Mr.Fox is a good book adaptation to the best selling novel thanks to its cast,funny humor,and impressive story and visual animation.
One of Dahl's best stories is given a nostalgic treatment by Anderson in this loving, but misguided and occasionally boring picture. It's an exercise in style with all of its substance removed.
Funny, twisted, fun, and lots of interesting eye candy, Fantastic Mr. Fox is fantastic!
I loved this book when I was a little kid and the movie didn't disappoint me!

The always-amazing Wes Anderson puts his distinctive mark on this modernised version of the Roald Dahl children's book.  Well animated, and the usual ensemble cast (albeit voices only) we've come to expect from Wes are joined by George Clooney and Meryl Streep.
For those who are studying post-modern irony, this is gold.
This movie's really quite a bit of a joke. The animation's quite stiff, and you really don't want the main character to win by the film's end.

Wes Anderson's animated masterpiece. A very smart and rare adaptation of Roald Dahl's classic story that actually manages to improve and expand upon the original. The writing is perfect. The characters are perfect. The animation is perfect. This movie is perfect.
this is a great stop motion film
Seems to me to have snobbiness about it's view towards children, by not making itself more accessible to them.

Fantastic.

I love seeing what Wes Anderson can go with what's given to him. 
I'm not sure if anyone really expected much from this movie based off of the Roald Dahl book, mainly since the quality of Dahl's movie adaptations has... varied over the years. And honestly the trailer just didn't really impress me the first time I saw it. 
But like most of Anderson's trailers, the final product ended up being much different from the trailer, this one being for the better. 
The script is very fast paced and fun, giving each character room to say something important or funny. The humor was also great for adults and kids to understand. I also really enjoyed how during the climax quite literally everything began falling apart. It helps show just how drastic things were getting. 
The character of Mr. Fox is kind of a mixed bag. You will either love or hate his mischievous ways. Some of his running gags last a bit too long but I personally liked him. He's charming without overdoing it. He (for the most part) realizes when he's made a mistake and tries to fix it or do what he can with what he's got. The side characters are very fun and quirky from the goofy Kristofferson (great name by the way) to the evil farmers, who also get a couple of good laughs ("You wrote a bad song, Petey! ") By the way, props to Desplat for another great soundtrack. 
The animation, although tough to get used to at first, looked great and unique. This is a film that, like most of Anderson's works, sets itself apart from others. It's animation, characters, camera work, and script all make this movie one of a kind. Whether or not it's unique in a good way is up to you, but personally this was a tasty treat that was wonderful to watch.

8/10 Amazing
Great animated film funny
Smug, but when isn't he?
not quite as magnificent as other films in the Wes Anderson universe, but still an ander-piece!
I love the animation, really good animation. I am a big fan of the book. Mr fox is on a journey. A really good movie.

One of the most original pieces of animation put together. Combining Wes Anderson style with animation couldn't have gone any better. His eye for detail is admiringly amusing, and the voice acting is spot on in this live action animation extravaganza. Clooney, Streep, schwartzman, Murray provide all the fun and laughter for any generation. It's truly appealing to any age and it should hold any movie goers attention. cinematography, score, and the direction are pure Wes Anderson and it's perfected to amazement. Truly a delightful animated film that seems to have changed the genre. Wes Anderson has a great eye for animation and it showed here.

I watched this on a whim and was rewarded with a big grin. It is clever, funny, and a delight from beginning to end. The dialogue was particularly witty. It's hard to imagine anyone from any age group that wouldn't get a kick out of it. I avoided it when it came out: I seem to have gotten the impression it was going to be some political allegory. Instead, it is like a watching a beautifully done cartoon that is both fun to watch and pulls gently on your heartstrings. Clooney was great, but Streep reined in her occasional tendency to over act and pulled off the role of Mrs. Fox with understated credibility. The characters, both animal and human, are a riot of well-crafted detail. I was really glad I caught it; wonderful movie.

I really loved this film, not just because its from my favorite director, because the animation is fluent and Wes Anderson's directing created a symmetrical style of cinematography, which his films are known for
An excellent return to form, The Fantastic Mr. Fox is cussing fantastic.
A charming, hilarious, and overall fantastic animated film, Wes Anderson's first animated film is also one of his best.

Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) - 7,5

Wes Anderson makes an incursion in Stop motion animation with another comedy. In this fantasy, we watch an amusing open war between 3 wealthy human farmers and alpha male Mr. Fox. After stealing poultry from 3 farms to satisfy his wild beast whims, Mr. Fox and his family have to dig for their lives when faced with the farmers' vengeful fury. Fortunately, this fantasy determines that the personified animals are as smart as people and in the end sly fauna takes the upper hand over Men. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is worth for the great visual beauty, for the rich characters and the very entertaining humor. Wes Anderson's steady hand in the direction and playful pathos prevents this movie from falling into mediocre territory. I would like to see substantially more facial expression from the animal characters, there were moments of emotional or otherwise persuasive agenda that didn't quite grip me as they could. Technical limitations, I suppose. Small distraction in such a colorful and lively movie. But then again, Wes' characters are never garish in their facial expressions. I was very curious to see how the director would forge his animated subjects and, unremarkably, they are not too different from live-action counterparts. Fun and beautiful animation movie, recommended.

"THREE FARMERS HUNTING DOWN A FOX"  

- Based on the novel of Roald Dahl (Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Mathilda) is this 2009 stop-motion animation film 'Fantastic Mr. Fox' directed by Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums, The Grand Budapest Hotel). The story is about the war between a fox and three farmers who got robbed of their animals. The film has a retro stylish look and is very suitable to watch with the kids. With the voices of George Clooney (From Dusk till Dawn, Ocean's Eleven), Meryl Streep (The Hours, Death Becomes Her), Jason Schwartzman (Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, The Grand Budapest Hotel), Bill Murray (Lost in Translation, Ghostbusters), Owen Wilson (Meet the Parents, Zoolander), Willam Dafoe (Spiderman, Antichrist), Brian Cox (X-men 2, Troy) and Adrien Brody (King Kong, Predators). 

Two years (12 fox years) after Mr. Fox (Clooney) and his wife Felicity (Streep) have given up their job of raiding farms, they live a normal boring life in a hole in the ground with their son Ash (Schwatzman). One day Mr. Fox decides to move to a luxurious tree, situated on a hill overseeing three farms. Every night he sneaks out of his home to raid one of the farms with the help of opossum Kyle. But it doesn't take long before the fat chicken farmer Walter Boggis, the little goose farmer Nathaniel Bunce and the tall turkey farmer Franklin Bean join forces to hunt down the thieves. Unwillingly Mr. Fox has endangered not only himself, but also his family and neighbors...
Smart, Funny and Original... Fantastic Mr. Fox adds another success to stop motion animation.

What book? But even though that should piss me off, it surprisingly doesn't, I think that has a lot to do with that it does stay true to the book but also strays away from it when it needs to, I'd say, this is a perfect movie to watch if you're not familiar with Wes' work, and if you are familiar with his work, this everything you and I love about Wes Anderson.

This animated outing by Wes Anderson is without a doubt one of the best animated films i have seen in a very, very long time. It's full of life, fun, intricacies that just blow your mind. Whats even more amazing is that even though this is an animated outing, you genuinly feel like your there, with the cinematography being constantly on the move, follwing the insane plots/manuevers that Mr Fox gets us into, its a work of genius. Mr and Mrs Fox, played by Clooney and Streep (Wonderfully i might add), spend their time hunting down chickens from farms and doing what foxes do. One day while on the steal, Mrs Fox confesses to Mr Fox she is pregnant and that this way of life must stop. Flash forward 12 years later, they have a kid called Ash, Mr Fox is a coloumist and everything seems hunky dory. However discontent with his lack of wealth and letting his nature take over, Mr fox decides to hatch a plan to raid three different farms, the results, not only destroy the animal community but also put Mr Foxes life and family at risk. The animation is so fresh to see in this day and age, this is a dying form and its so good to see it being put to good use here. The voice acting is astounding and hilarious, for the first time in an age Clooney gives a performance we were so used to from yesteryear. The usual people show up in smaller roles, trade mark Murray, but its absolutley fine and none jarring due to the animated nature. Willem DaFoe's rat however is just the pinncacle of hillarity at one point during the film, i wont spoil. I genuinley dont have a single bad word to say against this movie apart from its seems about 5 minutes to long, that however is barely a gripe. Excellent piece of cinema and animation, forget your toy stories and your Up!'s this, my friends, is where the magic is at.

Although it's completely stop motion, Wes Anderson gives a feeling of rawness and sincerity. His beautiful take on a new kind of film must be credited as a monumental moment, proving that Anderson's talents are like none other. Fantastic mr fox is smartly paced, knows it's morals, and has anyone of any age leaving with more than they expected.

I think you either 'get' Wes Anderson movies or you don't. By 'get', I mean a connection. It's maybe the unique way they are shot. Often square to the subject occasionally moving in a single direction. Or it's the detail crammed into every scene. It could be the no-nonsense dialog and the impeccable comic timing, or all the above. What ever it is - you 'get' it, and love Wes Anderson films. Or you don't, and you can't stand them. It's not a measure of intelligence. You either do or you don't. Happily for me, I 'get' his movies. They click, and that makes me happy! :-)

The Fantastic Mr. Fox is no exception. The stop-motion animation is superb, and really suits Wes Anderson's story telling style. The whole production is so bloody charming! Mr. Fox can't seem to control his basic animal instincts, and repeatedly (despite Mrs Fox's objections) snatches livestock from three neighboring farms. This then leads to a retaliatory strike by the farmers. Retaliation leads to escalation as the Fox family and their many friends escape the farmers and try to help themselves to everything the farmers have!

It all moves along at a great pace, and the script is sharp, surprising and always funny. I do however think this is going to appeal to big kids more.

Movie Prep:

If you remember the book by Roald Dahl, be warned the movie adds to the story. If you 'get' Wes Anderson's work then you're likely going to enjoy this too. The darker tone and humor in this story may not appeal to younger kids.

Best Format:

It is a visual treat, so a HD showing at home with the family could be fun.

Best element for me:

I loved the scenes with Mr. Fox's son, Ash (Jason Schwartzman.) A great character, trying to find his way out from under his fantastic father's shadow. He just gets the funniest dialog.

Ash: You're supposed to be *my* lab partner.

Agnes: I am!

Ash: No you're not. You're disloyal.

This movie can be viewed in two ways. 1.) those who are hardcore fans of the original story and 2.) those who are average movie goers. I view this one as both at once. It follows the book to a certain extent and they did add scenes that were unessecary and characters that were never in the book at all. The actors were great but I didn't see a character I saw/heard the actors being themselves. George Clooney plays a self centered fox that is boastful and a jerk. The opening is boring, now big introduction (I am not saying like a musical number or anything) but it just starts off like a powerpoint slideshow. Some scenes looked like they were rushed and never finished and I think this was a product of Wes Anderson self indulgent. Fantastic Mr. Fox is an impressive, and very different animated film, brought to us by the clever and bizarre Wes Anderson. The movie is a fully realized adaptation of Roald Dahl's book of the same name.

The story follows Mr. Fox who lives with his wife, and his young pup Ash. As soon as Mr. Fox learned he would be having a kid, he decided to get out of the chicken stealing business for good. Although, he missed it, he took up work as a columnist for the local newspaper. One day, Mr. Fox announces how displeased he is with being poor, denouncing the absurd idea of living in a 'fox hole'. Soon, Fox and his buddies team up to rob the three big farms in town of all their chicken and alcoholic apple cider. The schemes are smart and sly, but draw enough attention to initiate all out war between the animals and the farmers.

This is easily one of the more interesting animated movies I've seen. First off, the story is nothing ground breaking. It's a funny one, but nothing that's completely outside the box. That being said, it's still a good story. The one thing you first notice with Fantastic Mr. Fox, is it's awesome animation style. There are a lot of beautifully 3D rendered animations coming out all the time, but it's once in a blue moon a filmmaker comes out and injects something new into the same old song and dance. Not only that, but Wes Anderson gives the film a great balance of humor that caters to both children and adults. All great voice overs from Clooney, Streep, Bill Fucking Murray, and Schwartzman.

Along with his familiar cast, Wes Anderson did not forget to bring in his style when creating this one. It's a Wes Anderson through and through, and by now his style has helped create a name for himself. It's abstract, weird, awkward, and clever, with razor sharp banter like dialogue. The writing is one of the stand out key elements beyond the great animation and art direction. I love the style of this movie though. It's like Wes Anderson didn't decide to just make a movie about Roald Dahl's book, but made it his own. He put the Anderson stamp on it, and it feels like every one of his other movies, which is awesome. It's like if Scorcese one day decided to create a cartoon film about the mafia crime scene. It might be a toned down cartoon, but you know who made it even if the form of film is not traditional to the filmmaker.

Although, the movie is great in many aspects, I didn't feel the heartwarming vibe it tried going for. There's a moral to this story, but it's somewhat squandered beyond the constant dry joking character interaction. It's subtle and deadpan humor, that kind of fails to insert that loving, moral bit. The movie could go on even longer than it did, although that could possibly ruin it too. It's a short, fun, cartoon, that could make anyone smile. That's the one thing that makes this one fresh.

Peeked into the foxhole and found myself a little hidden gem here. There are a fair share of silly jokes which is right up my alley while even some of the not-so-hilarious content seems funnier due to the well executed quick paced dialogue from the voice actors. The story itself moves at the same quick speed as well which works great since there is practically no useless filler material, making it very hard for anyone to lose interest. They often use different camera angles for the escape/rescue scenes which adds another dimension to the storytelling while also invoking a few more laughs. Much like Pingu (anyone remember that?) or Robot Chicken (anyone heard of that?), 'Fantastic Mr Fox' uses stop-motion animation. This distinguishes it from what has become your bog standard cartoon animations of late, allowing it to implement its own unique styles of visual humour.

A wonderful animated feature that captures the idiosyncrasies found in wild animals to create a rather ironic and thoughtful narrative. The existentialist crises that haunt these animals seem to touch on our human, albeit mammalian, lives as well. It is ironic that the viewer will find him/herself connecting more with the animals than the human counterparts. To the mechanical side of things, the script moves at a dutifully brisk pace with nary a dull moment and the voice acting is simply superb. This is one feature that can appeal to the entire spectrum of viewers, either aging or incredibly young: a feat that is seldom achieved in an animated feature. Wes Anderson's vision was ahem, spot on!

If one watches it and disregards that it's a children's book originally, one would ask themselves "what the heck is the point of this thing???" despite it being rather entertaining. Also, the actors did an excellent job with the voice-over, especially George Clooney, and it was lovely to hear Meryl Streep's voice!

Overall, it is definitely a good film, but keep in mind that it does not necessarily have a point to it. It's a children's story turned into a film. Fun, but not very deep/challenging

It's soooooO BORING NO PLOT and the weird fox family says they r sooo poor when they have a house that a normal human being would have and they even have a pool! They even steal things..... Bad examples 4 kids.
One of the best and most innovative movie I ever watched in stop motion. Wes Anderson delivers with a clever writing and great characters.

Roald Dahl's masterpiece again finally realized? Hmm...

Wes Anderson may not just be one of the best directors who I think needs to direct a blockbuster, but you could even make the argument that there is a huge resemblance to what this movie, Fantastic Mr. Fox means to me. Not only do I think its one of the greatest animated features of all times, but I do think it has stuck on to me like glue.

Here is what stood out to me, the stuff with the characters are UNBELIEVABLE. This has probably one of the best mixed casts I have ever seen. Not that I haven't seen this before, since he tends to use the same actors over and over. And the fact that they even address this issue just makes it even more interesting. 

For a short review, Fantastic Mr. Fox has been added to my all-time favorite movie collections. 

If you haven't seen it, check it out and decide for yourself.

This would have to be in my opinion, one of the best animated features to come out for the last few years. It's got that idiosyncratic Wes Anderson goodness that I love, a lot of very entertaining and vivid characters. Some really interesting stop motion, very detailed but purposely un-fluid, especially compared to the works of Aardman. Great entertainment and definitely worth your time.
Relentless in it's intricately amusing ways, Fantastic Mr Fox is animated perfectly and written with an abundance of intelligence and wit.

anderson's surreal wit and off kilter humour is at work once again and I thought this was quite the joyful ride. anderson and company make the most of the roal dahl novel while keeping the quirky laughs and unique animation choices going. first time rating: 8.5/10

One of the best animation films I ever seen. Very smart, great animations-- which I'm not a big fan of stop motion-- good laughs, awesome voice overs, and the movie has a great fantasy feel. The movie may be to sophisticated for little children, but I loved every bit of the fantastic ness of Mr. Fox.

This is the stupidest animated film I have ever seen!!! There's no plot!!! It's not even funny!!! If anything they teach kids to lye because the fox family said they're poor and they got a swimming pool!! And they just steal things!!! And the Mr. Fox dude gets electrocuted yet he doesn't die!!! Is this Sponge Bob all over again?!?! Like Seriously!!!!
Great kids movie top 20, also a good book
Great movie. Except for some of the humor. Some of it I didn't get. But it was still a very entertaining movie.
Fantastic mr. Fox is as funny, cunning and inventive as its foxes.

I love Pixar.  However this movie made me so happy, to a point that Pixar hasn't ever made me.  To see other directors start to employ animation to create stories whose maturity and clever humor blur the line between adult audiences and children's audiences is drastically needed.  I think Wes Anderson may be the guy to make that connection.  This sh---cuss is brilliance.

Amazing visuals with terrific voice acting make for one of the strangest and most unique animated films ever made. It's retreading ground from Anderson's other films (and is never quite as profound or moving), but the whole thing is utterly charming and often very funny. The dance sequences in particular are joyous. A cussing great movie.
This was so good, refreshingly quirky in Wes Andersons unique way.
being a big George Clooney fan, this film was just the best, and Wes Anderson being another fantastic director.
Amazing, one of the best animated movies I've ever seen.
Funny little stop motion gem, with Wes Anderson's signature humor.

Great animation, excellent dialogue, wit, and dark twists, make this tale of thievery one of the best adaptions of any book, let alone one of Clooney's best films (second only to Up in the Air). Even though this is a mildly-hard PG movie, you should not rob your kids of this film. If you enjoyed Chicken Run and Wallace & Gromit: Curse of the Were-Rabbit (though Fox is not as good as these), you will enjoy this, as it is the best claymation movie in a long time.
This movie was pretty awesome.  Great for fans both young and old. Very well done Mr. Anderson.
I was laughing all the way through this one.

Very rarely do I finish a movie and immediately press "play" and watch it again. A perfect movie, one that is light yet meaningful and so much fun to watch. The characters are well fleshed out and the soundtrack moves it along like the first time on a wooden roller coaster.

I'm not a fan of clay animation, but i have to say Fantastic Mr. Fox is simply beautiful. Boasted by great voice acting an ensemble cast and fresh witty writing. Wes Anderson's fantastic animated masterpiece is pleasurable to watch and provides the audience with alot of genuine laughs.
very well done and funny. the stop motion animation sets it apart as well. just a cute little movie. :)
Fantastic Mr. Fox is a very creative and delightful movie. It has comedy and action and for a cartoon, I must say this film is just amazing like it's animation.
Love it! Cuse, this is an awesome flick

It has plenty of good laughs, and good dialog for a kids movie, but it's plot is nothing if not cliched, and it is riddled with moments of awkwardness, and the animation is a little too cartoonish to be tolerable.
intellectual comedy with the most perfect eccentricity of Wes Anderson

A delightful, brilliantly animated heist caper that is amusing and entertaining on every level.  From the pitch perfect voice work, the brilliant and classy stop-motion animation, the bizarre and snappy humor, the zany plot, the lovable characters; Fantastic Mr. Fox is a gem of a animated film.  I have so much respect for directors who think outside the box like Wes Anderson.  What could have been a simple cash-in is a memorable tale with so much care taken to create a stop-motion film, and that is commendable enough.  A film I dearly enjoy and would watch again and again!
Absolutely Hilarious
OMG loved this movie so much one of my most favorite movie of all time i loved the characters and the awesome storyline 5 out of 5 stars truly amazing.

This is a treat to the eyes and mind. Anderson delivers his standard style to this film and it pays off ten fold. It is clever, cute, and a tad tripy. It has such a mellow sense of humor and a very good direction about it you can't help but too giggle!

I'm a sucker for awesome dialogue and animation. Especially, this rare animation and Anderson is a unique and extravagant director/writer. I honestly was also struck by the "waterfall" scene, it made me so happy to see something different and amazing.

Definitely one of the most innovative animation films I've ever seen in terms of how it was filmed. I was partially swept away by the typical Wes Anderson charm, and impressed with the occasional dark turns the film would take.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is a fantastic (sorry, had to do it) art-house animated movie that's firing on all cylinders; it's got a great ensemble and an atypical screenplay coupled with eye-popping visual flair -- just don't expect this to be a wild ride as you would imagine a wild ride to be. The VISUALS are wild and eccentric, and there may be quirky moments within the plot, but "Fantastic Mr. Fox" keeps its composure throughout.

An incredibly unique film, with an all-star cast, brilliant design, and lots of appeal. Funny, interesting, and nothing like anything you've ever seen, Fantastic Mr. Fox should be a guide for making animated films.

I have always sticked with Wes Anderson even when his movies did not succeed. His last few films have been duds, but Fantastic Mr. Fox is nothing but a hit. The stop motion animation is excellent and sets the quirky tone for the rest of the film. Anderson and his screenwriter Noah Baumbauch throw in inside jokes and adult humor without being self-indulgent or crude. Great use of music throughout plus plenty of great voice acting especially by Schwartzman and Wes Anderson's own brother Eric. A visually successful film that is creatively and meticulously designed. A true triumph of animated filmmaking and Anderson becomes one of the few live action filmmakers to be successful in animation arts.

Astonishingly tedious.  For a while we wondered if it were intended to deliberately be tedious, as some sort of parody - but no, it seems as if the idea really was to use stiffly animated animals to imitate what stiff, boring people do.

It might be that the last hour was better - we couldn't make it through past the first one.  Not one laugh in the whole thing...
Leave it to Wes Anderson to be better than most at displaying what grand ideas a children's tale can behold.

The Roald Dahl classic tale of a sly fox battling a group of angry farmers tired of sharing their chickens with him comes to life in this sublime stop motion animation venture of director Wes Anderson that has a visual depth that most modern animation films lack, with its unique style that represents a true auteur's vision. And while the talking animals and the animation may hide the thematic depth, this film is no less compelling than the other works by the renowned filmmaker but rather more universal and able to capture wider audiences.

Nothing negative to say here.  I was smiling ear to ear throughout.  Except for the oft instances that Anderson always squeezes in when the character discovers something powerfully emotional about his/her existence.  Fuck, I loved this movie.  One of the year's best.  Unless, you hate Wes Anderson, which I know some of you do.  Even so, it's one of his most accessible and enjoyable.  Apparently, a lot of people have been complaining about the Americanization of Dahl's book.  I read the book as a kid, but not with a British accent.  I can see how some might be pissed, but this aspect really did not bother me.  It's an adaptation, not an audio book.

It's too weird, strange, off-beat, and not to forget dull for me to like when Up, Wallace & Gromit, and even Caroline are waaaaaayyyyy better cartoon movies than this one. I might go as far as saying even Cars 2 was better
Fantastic Mr. Fox is a very enjoyable movie with amazing visuals and clever writing.
A great animation movie. Fantastic Mr. Fox feels like an adult fairy tale that will entertain the whole family.

A great film. Clooney is perfectly cast in a lovely post Oh Brother role with a similar character feel. The story is a delight and the stop motion animation coveys and evokes more emotion than you would think possible. Great for kids and grown ups alike.
Fantastic Mr. Fox is truly a one of a kind animated film that adults will enjoy as much as, if not more than, their children. I loved it. R.I.P Roald Dahl
This movie caught me by surprise! it was funny, witty and suspenseful. I would watch it again in a heart beat.
I wish I had watched this sooner. One of the most clever, hilarious, and silly movies I have ever seen.
classic wes anderson attached to a classic story.

Fantastic Mr. Fox was just that: fantastic! The stop motion was just short of amazing. Very fluid movement throughout, facial expressions remarkable, and the scenery exquisite! The voice actors were quite adept at delivering Anderson's and Noah Baumbach's dialogue with the familiar dry wit we see in their previous efforts. Loved the use of the word "cuss" in place of any and all curse words; makes the film family friendly without turning into a droll kids flick. Will surely be adding to my collection.
I saw this movie in the theaters with my Dad and we both loved it!

I watched this back when it was in theaters, knowing in a vague way who Wes Anderson was and that he was a famous director. I got most of my knowledge about him from Bryce. I feel, after loving Moonrise Kingdom so much this past summer, if I watched this movie again I would love it even more. I'm pretty sure I saw this with Bryce in theaters, but maybe other people were there too.
Animations are great and although the story in itself is not brilliant, you will have a smile on your face throughout the movie.
i can't stop doing the fox whistle someone help me
Wes Anderson's stop motion film is a great amount of fun. Anderson's style is here and is enjoyable, but its the stop motion animation is what makes the film fantastic.
Well animated, nice character designs and presentation. A visual treat despite being stop motion animation.

Lots of laughs very
funny fami oriented over all very good movie
Brilliant! The characters, the mood, the story, the dialogue..

Wes Anderson again steals the show without even acting. His definitive art style is on full display in this animated, stop-motion film that connects with me at a younger age as well as now. Outside of Pixar, this is the best animated movie of all time.
Wes Anderson brings his style to this stop-motion film about a fox on a job. The characters are fun and have their own 'fursonalities'. It is a short film suitable for the whole family.
Very funny but not a big cartoon person.
Brilliant comedy for the Mums and Dads as well as the kiddies...

Wasn't that keen on watching it but I caught it on TV over Christmas and got really into it, The choice of filming was different but it works, It's pretty funny and very well done and with a great voice cast it's worth watching.
Daddy issues, wry dialogue, humor so dry it makes you thirsty, and 90 degree camera angles are just a few tools a director can use.  To Wes Anderson, they seem to be ALL of them.

This wasn't a movie that I thought I'd be seeing at the cinema - however I liked this movie more than I expected.  

There are some very clever moments, and perhaps moments that are a bit above the standard intellect of a child (the film's target audience I would have thought), but not knowing the source material all that well I didn't know whether this was unusual or not.  Maybe it was just me.

There is no doubt that George Clooney is very good as the Fantastic Mr. Fox.  I didn't feel the same about Meryl Streep's character - and I actually found her a touch annoying.  My favourite character was 'Kristofferson' and thought any time he was on screen something funny happened.

All in all, a surprisingly positive experience!
Dahl and Anderson are a perfect combination in a warm-hearted family comedy
Turning my favorite book when I was a kid into a movie turned out to be a great success.
Can't help it. This is fantastic.

Finally! A pretty good Wes Anderson film. So, I'm prepared to revise my earlier statement. I will never watch a live action Wes Anderson film again. But if he makes another animation, I may want to see it.
This movie was pretty fantastic.
With talented voice actors, sharp humor, and uniquely old-fashioned while fresh at the same time, Wes Anderson triumphs with stop-motion and Roald Dahl's unfailing spirit.
A piece of high design mixed with the most curious plot.

I saw this awhile back and happened to rewatch it with my family tonight, and I must say enjoyed the film much more the second time. I found myself laughing quite a bit, and was surprised how perfectly paced it was. The film is short, but feels that way even more so because constant state of fun and engagement. Also just a great cast of voice actors. I'm surprised Anderson doesn't venture into more animation, the field seems so suited for him.

Enormously different from the book (which absolutely must be read first, if you ever plan on reading it any way), but that doesn't detract from its humor, style, wit, artistic interpretation...  Very amusing watch.

Well now we know that be it animation or live action, Wes Anderson still maintains his distinctive style of storytelling as well as filmmaking. Fantastic Mr. Fox is a movie completely different from mainstream animated movies. Throughout the movie its has more of a live action feel and also the narrative style is suited more towards the older crowds making it pretty obvious that the choice of it being an animated film was just for the ease of creating the characters.
As far as the movie goes, it hits all the checkpoints,
-good story
-good character 
-great voice acting

The animation was just basic stuff nothing out of the ordinary but it was pretty obvious that he paid more attention to the story details, being a better live action director compared to an animation director.
All in all its a standard Wes Anderson movie you would come to expect!
Fantastically clever, quirky, and hilarious.  Pokes fun at a lot of movie stereotypes without losing itself in spoof and irony.
My favourite animation!
Hilarious, distracting, full of references. Who said animation was only for kids ? Anderson certainly is fantastic.
It effortlessly balances comedy, wit, beautiful animation, and a well-paced and interesting plot line that never takes itself too seriously. A MUST SEE for adults and children alike.
Probably the most satisfying movie I have seen in a long while. It's charming and breathes Wes Anderson. Which is one thing that makes this movie so intriguing.

SUMMARY: A slick but down on his luck fox quits pulling heists for a while but then wants to pull one last big one which is on a bunch of wealthy owners. REVIEW: I actually  watched this twice. The first time I wasn't sure but after the second I actually loved it. With the voice talents of George Clooney and Bill Murray this movie was very fun and also quite humerous.  It also introduces a different kind of animation than other movies. It's an entertaining  fun movie. It's my first of Wes Anderson's films that I have seen and although not the greatest it still holds up in it's humor enough to make the movie worth a watch.

So i finally watched Fantastic Mr. Fox , pure WTF Movie , full of awesome fun , i want to be critical about the whole moral system at play but the cuteness of the foxes is ohh sooo deceiving for me to ignore it , if it was any other movie i would have done it but this is just too charming , 7/10 from me
"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is Fantastic!
It all looked like a dream I once had.
That was something else! I needed ~10 min to get used to the jittery, 2.5 dimensional animation, but it's really delightful!
The weirdest snapping movie ever! (Noah and Hannah highly enjoyed it though)

Watched it for the first time last night, and loved it! A classic Wes Anderson touch takes liberties with, but does not ruin, a great book by Mr. Dahl. If anything, it makes it more interesting. And the soundtrack deserves its own special mention.

The Fantastic Mr. Fox seems like a children's movie, but there's so much more to it beneath the surface (pun intended). Not only does Anderson capture the feel of Dahl's story, but he manages to capture his own signature style in a completely new medium without making it overwhelmingly so. The script captures the whimsy of both Dahl and Anderson, the dialogue is witty and snappy, and the characters are well-rounded and well-formed. The movie itself  is visually striking, and it presents one of the more significant achievements in animation in the past decade - a nice contrast to all of the CGI movies being released. In short, this movie is cussing hilarious, and I love the cuss out of it.

Well it's no Charlie and Chocolate Factory or Matilda but it's still decent. I'd say it's closer in feel to James and the Giant Peach. It was a pleasant enough movie with interesting animation but the storyline wasn't all that appealing to me. Also, the majority of the humor was a little dry for my taste but it was still quirky fun.

Wes Anderson is without a doubt the weirdest director ever. Fantastic Mr. Fox, like Moonrise Kingdom, is a whimsical and sweet movie about being true to yourself. He had a lot to say about the world we live in now; what it is that drives us. Continually digging holes could not be more spot on. George Clooney had the easiest job of his career by just putting on a quirky voice and reading lines. There's a lot to be had here. The stop-motion adds to Anderson's style. I don't think this movie is for everyone, but it was entertaining and very thought provoking, especially for an animated movie. Very funny, and very sweet.
fox,badgers,beavers and off course humans  ensemble for a wholesome entertainer from wes craven.comical and surreal mr.fox is brilliant.

Funnier and better than I thought it was going to be. If you liked Rushmore and Royal Tenenbaums, you'll like this great visual animated movie. They avoided an "R" rating by having all the characters actually say "cuss" instead of cussing. Example: "Well this is a nice cluster cuss. You son of a cuss." It's quite funny as you watch the movie plus the animation is very well done.
Not only the best animation of 2009 but also the best thing Anderson has ever done
More than manages to channel Wes Anderson's signature humor into a children's vehicle.
Love it its very interesting and entertaining
Was not expecting such a great film when I came upon it one afternoon on T.V - thought it was for kids but proved me wrong within 5 minutes. So clever, cannot recommend enough.
Unforgettable , Wonderfully cartoon filled with heartwarming story. Truly one of the best.
Astounding animation, messages for both kids and adults, and pure fun. What more could you want in a fantastic film?
A wonderfully animated film, that's charming, touching, and humorous.
Charming! I thoroughly enjoyed this. Animation is a perfect medium for Wes Anderson.
Well on its way to becoming a cult classic for sure. Very quotable and highly addictive.
Good family adventure movie...I'm sure Wes Anderson fans will love it.
This movie literally made me want to shoot myself in the face.
Neat animation with Wes Anderson's whimsical touch.
A F@&$ing Great Little movie.
One of the coolest, funniest and greatest films of all time. 5/5. Must watch and Wes Anderson's best!

This movie actually bored me to tears. Who would've thought that George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Owen Wilson, and Bill Murray together in the same animated feature would be a complete flop?!?! Some people may praise the indie humour and different animation style; but besides the voice acting,  I thought this was downright unentertaining.

It was delightfully refreshing.  Like other Wes Anderson films, it was inhabited by quirky interesting charecters full of charm and depth. I was suprised at the expertise of the animation.  It really showed the versatility of the medium. The close up shots of the faces show a great emotional depth.  Possibly the best stop motion animation film since the "Nightmare Before Christmas" maybe even better.

Elevated by quirky animation and a plethora of great character moments, Fantastic Mr Fox is yet further proof that Wes Anderson is one of the most talented and unique directors working in Hollywood today.

Wes Anderson Has Made Yet Another Masterpiece. "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is Dazzling To Behold. The Film Takes A Simple And Beloved Children's Story And Transforms It Into A Magnificent Work Of Art. The Animation Is Amazing And Wonderfully Quirky. Anderson's Critics Complain That His Aesthetic Does Not Allow For Realism And His Characters Feel Artificial. With An Animated Film, Anderson Can Be As Creative And Audacious As He Needs To Be And Still Provide Emotional Truth While Creating Vibrant And Wonderfully Eccentric Characters. Anderson Co-Wrote The Screenplay With Noah Baumbach, The Writer-Director Of "Greenberg", "Margot At The Wedding", And "The Squid And The Whale". The Voices Include George Clooney, Eric Anderson, Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray, Meryl Streep, Owen Wilson, And Willem Dafoe. All Of Them Are Brilliant And Absolutely Hysterical. The Film Is One Of The Finest Films I Have Seen In Years. It Ranks Among Anderson's Other Great Works Such As "Rushmore" And "The Royal Tenenbaums" "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is The Single Greatest Animated Film That I Have Ever Seen. The Film Is Emotionally Resonant And Incredibly Heartwarming. This Film Made Me Feel Alive In A Way That Few Other Films Have. Wes Anderson's "Fantastic Mr. Fox" Is One Of The Very Best Films Of The Decade.
Not as good as Moonrise Kingdom but still a fantastic movie with some great animation and just as wired as all of Wes Anderson's movies.

Lush autumn visuals, typical intricate Wes Anderson visuals with an animated twist, memorable characters and a script packed with witticisms make Fantastic Mr. Fox truly enjoyable fare. Its voice cast with such names as George Clooney, Meryl Streep and Jason Schwartzman add weight to an already lovely mix, with a fox outsmarting a slew of farmers and other humans in this film based on Roald Dahl's children's book.
Bringing its own style of quirky stop-motion animation to the table, Fantastic Mr. Fox is a well-crafted adaptation of the fabulous Roald Dahl novel.
More a Wes Anderson movie than a conventional children's animated film, and is all the better off for it.  Funny and touching
Fantastic in every way.
best animated film of 2009
Hilarious, tender, and with quirky animation that Wes Anderson pulls off beautifully, Fantastic Mr. Fox can be thoroughly enjoyed by children and adults alike.

Easily the best movie I've seen all year. It's so original and witty, It's easily reached my top ten list of all-time favourites Every time I watch it I see something new that adds to the plot, every detail is so interwoven into the rest of the story, it's impossible not to fall in love! I highly recommend, one of Anderson's best works!
Well, i never read the children's book. So i don't know if the film does it any justice or not. But in it's own right, it's as "fantastic" as one would expect a Wes Anderson movie to be.
Enjoyed every minute!  Wonderful!

Stop animation, Roald Dahl, and Wes Anderson style = awesomeness

2009 Movies: 125
A piece of brilliance clothed in an out-of-the-ordinary style. It's fast-paced, quirky and absolutely kickass.
I really thought the movie was over and was ready to say that I liked it but it turned out to be a little over halfway done. Got bored. Stayed bored. Real bored.
Mr. Fox: "The cuss am I? Are you cussing with me?" Badger (Bill Murray): "No, you cussing with me?" Mr. Fox: "Don't cussing point at me!"  And so the battle begins.

A stop motion delight from Wes Anderson. Clooney as a thieving Fox is perfect casting. It’s fun and quick and has Anderson’s fast paced quirky style. Would’ve liked more out of the family to better pay off some of the heart.
You cussing with me?!?

I couldn't decide whether to give this film 0% or 100% ... such an off-kilter and confusing medley of ideas and action, Fantastic Mr. Fox is either one of the greatest movies ever made or one of the stupidest: I honestly have difficulty determining.
One of the best movies ever
George Clooney is awesome.  It's technically a kid's movie, but it's almost not.

Awesome animation and great vocal performances and some pretty funny jokes. Wes Anderson manages to bring his unique style to a kids movie without making it too juvenile for his fans to enjoy. The 'cuss' thing did get old quick though. I was pulling for Fantastic Mr. Fox to snatch the Academy Award for best animated feature, but alas.
Wonderfully done and well made.

My ONLY complaint is that I would have preferred 24 frames per second versus twelve. Amusingly, I can't imagine why children would really care for this, it is straight-up Wes Anderson in the best way possible.
The truest Roald Dahl adaptation since Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Marvellous.
The stop motion is below average..... LOVE Roald Dahl! Favorite children's author.
11/28/09 - Fantastic Mr. Fox was funny with quirky adult humor.  It was very interesting to see Wes Anderson translated to a kids audience via Roald Dahl.
Fun to watch, interesting characters and great voice acting. Another Wes Anderson movie magic.

As a fan of the book written by Roald Dahl, the story itself is predictable: A family of foxes goes out to nick food from three farmers named Boggis, Bunce and Bean and so do other woodland animals but when the farmers find out, that their food is slowly going missing because of those animals, one of the farmers tries to shoot them down but it's up to the animals to get together to get together and win over the three farmers and get the food they need to stop themselves from starving. Fantastic Mr.Fox the movie adaptation itself is fantastic. I guess I could argue that a lot of scenes that weren't from the book were added to the movie to make the film longer but that's just nitpicking. Overall this movie has it's target audience handled well and the film itself has spot-on animation and unbelievable voice-acting. Fantastic Mr.Fox gets a 9.5/10.
The visual style is so jarring that it makes the story seem reasonable by comparison. This is every bit a Wes Anderson film, wonderfully quirky and surprisingly engaging.

I liked it though it has flaws which of course are on purpose. I feel that it is a parody of bland, idiotic, and predictable kids movies. This evidenced by the fact that we cannot connect with any of these characters.
Gives RUSHMORE a run for its money as Wes Anderson's masterpiece. Perhaps the greatest Roald Dahl adaption and one of the great modern animated films. A true treasure.

Strange, witty, and beautifully animated. Fantastic Mr. Fox is at heart a spaghetti western with elements of the classic caper film. Add a few nods to classic cinema like M.A.S.H. and Citizen Kane, and we have another brilliant Wes Anderson film.

Great! 

My non-use of the word "fantastic" was entirely intentional. I just want you to know that. 

...but it was pretty fantastic.

Fantastic Mr. Fox is one of the best animated features of the last decade. It leaves behind the sentimentality of most successful (and "Disney-fied") animated movies, in favor, of an off-beat, adventure story that ultimately still brings about a fulfilling ending. Mr. Fox discovers that he'll always be a wild animal and that this is okay; he does not need to try to be someone else to please his family. As long as he cares about them, he will always be fantastic.

So damn weird, it's classic. Brilliant, brilliant humour. As quotable as Anchorman.
It's a true adaptation of the book; it doesn't just recreate it in film form but actually adds to it.
Seeing a fox limbering up has to be one of the most satisfying openings of a film ever. 
Probably my favourite children's film.

This film is Wes Anderson at his very best.  What a great way to reintroduce, revitalize, and re-imagine stop motion animation.  Plus, an amazing ensemble cast makes Fantastic Mr. Fox impossible to resist.  Any viewer will instantly become engrossed in the tale that is told.
Roald Dahl's vision exactly.

Love the mood and atmosphere that Wes Anderson is now masterful at. Fantastic visuals and sound make Fantastic Mr. Fox an enjoyable film. Wes Anderson's ability at inserting odd, yet effective musical interludes and witty dialogues has really become his trademark. Anderson also has the knack at coming up with the most interesting characters, and since this is a animations, these characters are accompanied by hilarious animal or human models. Although the story is really rather simplistic, but there is a deeper value in its simplicity, underneath the plot lies a lesson about human nature.
This will be remembered along the lines of Willie Wonka. A modern-day classic.

I was expecting a product more kids aimed so i was pleaseantly surprised instead  by the fact this is a real movie, witty, well crafted and magnifically voiced. Clooney lend the voice to the lead charachter, a fox that has hidden for years his  thief nature in order to be a perfect family man. But when he buys a new property he find out his neighbours are three rich farmers. His old nature come back on surface as he plans on making a loot out of the neighbours' properties. Animation is in stop motion, it looks stunning and agreable, the whole work have worth a Oscar Nominee for this movie, also the score by Desplat is a delight. Highly Recommended.
You can't deny there's something... different about this flick.

Although the length is 22 mins long It's done remarkably well and entertaining for the whole family on an odd but well written screenplay with an assembled cast. It's the first Wes Anderson film I've seen.
A great kids movie that should have done better at the box office.

Some voices don't match characters too well, and the dancing's kind of random. But it's a visual delight with sharp framing & the beautifully old-fashioned style. The script shows Roald Dahl's tale with some remarkable depth, easy humour and multiple themes that hide the sad lack of emotional connection, and the two leads George Clooney & Meryl Streep work breathlessly with their characters.

It never ceases to amaze me how Wes Anderson does not let his audience down in any cinematic endeavor he undertakes. Fantastic Mr. Fox is a fun, and witty caper guaranteed to bring a smile to your face.
Quirky, funny, and all-in-all wonderful!

A fable that is well directed and acted and offers a different pace and look than most, which is ultimately its success and its downfall. While the film is visually appealing it also is at times quite boring.
Interesting movie with a good cast. Fun and fast paced.
Love this movie too much

This movie will someday be an absolute classic. Leave it to Wes Anderson to create a quirky, and hilarious new hit. The combination of precision in the directing and Alexandre Deplat's soundtrack makes the movie a unique tale of a dysfunctional family, with a bit of a wild side. Wes Anderson's take on inspirational writer Roald Dahl's famous children's book Fantastic Mr. Fox may not be fantastic, however you could go far worse as far as animations are concerned. 

Anderson already has our attentions gripped with one glance at the star studded and family style casting. 

George Clooney as the smooth talking Mr Fox was almost meant to be - written in the stars if you will. He is the perfect choice for a family animation as his voice is heart warming and gentle; this is why he should have stayed well away of the Batman role in 1997.

Also cast is comedy legend Bill Murray, Meryl Streep, the veteran Williem Dafoe and Owen Wilson. Each deliver amicable performances which can be deemed acceptable by any standard. A solid back up cast.

If you are unfamiliar with the plot of Fantastic Mr. Fox is basically follows the journey of Mr. Fox and his family as they attempt to avoid the merciless capture of three farmers.

There are some nice touches to this film and it has a quirky feel throughout; although as I am familiar with the story it didn't have much else to offer. A decent tale on Dahl's book - a decent animation truth be told - just not a great one.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox" is a great family/stop-motion animated film (nominated for the Oscar for Best Animated Feature; lost to "Up") & stays faithful to the children's book by late author Roald Dahl; if Dahl were alive, I'm quite sure he would love this film.
